A TSS that is “conformant” with this document shall:
·       not support SNMP versions prior to SNMPv3 (i.e., there is no mechanism to activate prior versions of SNMP).
·       only support protocols providing equivalent security to SNMPv3 per the rules of NTCIP 2301 v03.
A TSS that is “consistent” with this document shall:
·       Support protocols providing equivalent security to SNMPv3 per the rules of NTCIP 2301 v03
·       Support less secure protocols (e.g., prior versions of SNMP)
·       Allows users to disable all protocols that are less secure than SNMPv3 according to NTCIP 2301 v03.
Implementations should support the communications stack defined in NTCIP 2301 v03.
This section is intended for product developers such as manufacturers and system integrators. Others might find this section and Section 5 helpful to gain a greater understanding of design details.

This section presents the standardized dialogs (i.e., sequence of data exchanges) that fulfill various requirements. As SNMP communications are largely driven by the management station, most of the requirements define how the device responds to various possible actions a management station might take.

The NTCIP standards effort is based on SNMP. This protocol offers a high degree of flexibility as to how the management station structures its requests. For example, with SNMP, the management station can do any of the following:

a)     Send only those requests that are critical at the current time, whereas a standardized dialog typically sends requests relating to all associated data, regardless of whether it is critical for current purposes.
b)     Combine a number of requests in a single packet, whereas a standardized dialog dictates the exact contents of each packet.
c)     Separate a group of requests into multiple packets, whereas a standardized dialog dictates the exact contents of each packet.
d)     Interweave requests from multiple dialogs, whereas a standardized dialog dictates the exact ordering of messages, which are not interrupted with other messages.

This flexibility can be a powerful tool, allowing a management station to optimize the use of communications facilities. This is the primary reason that SNMP was chosen as the core NTCIP protocol; however, the flexibility also means that there are numerous allowable variations in the management process that a management station may choose to use.

This flexibility also presents a challenge to ensuring interoperability. While a conformant TSS is required to support any allowed sequence in this document, ensuring that a given TSS actually supports every possible combination would be impractical. Instead, most agencies only require that the device be tested to a standard set of procedures, which would use standardized dialogs. To improve communications efficiency, management stations may use non-standard dialogs (e.g., a combination of GetRequest-PDUs and/or SetRequest-PDUs that is not defined as a standardized dialog, but which a conformant device is required to support (i.e., according to the state transitions defined in Section 4.3, the SYNTAX and MAX-ACCESS clauses of Section 5, and the object refinements defined in A.7.. Because these more efficient dialogs may not be known until the acquisition of the management station, which may be years after the acquisition of the device, there is a potential for an interoperability problem to arise.

To overcome this complication, this section defines a lowest common denominator approach to communications between a management station and a TSS. It defines the standardized dialog for each Data Exchange Requirement defined in Section 3. Management stations may support other dialogs to fulfill these same requirements, as long as these dialogs are consistent with the rules defined in this document. Such a management station is termed a 'consistent management station'. A consistent management station interoperates with any 'conformant' TSS. However, since an agency cannot be certain that a TSS is 100% conformant in every possible scenario (given practical constraints), interoperability issues could still arise.

A 'conformant management station' is required to offer a mode in which it only uses the standardized dialogs as defined in this section. With this limited definition, there is relatively little variability in what constitutes a conformant management station, and fully testing a management station for conformance is a relatively straightforward process that can be done within the practical constraints faced by most procuring agencies. A conformant management station provides an agency with a much greater chance of achieving a base level of interoperability with off-the-shelf devices that have been tested against this document.
The rules for the standardized dialogs follow:

a)     The dialogs contain a number of GetRequest-PDUs, GetNextRequest-PDUs, GetBulkRequest-PDUs, and SetRequest-PDUs. These requests shall follow the rules defined in NTCIP 2301, which references RFC 3416. Each specified request shall be transmitted as a single message.

b)     The contents of each request are identified by an object name. Each object name consists of an object type and an instance identifier. Formal definitions of each object type are provided within the MIB associated with the object type in the RTM, as defined in Annex A. The meaning of the instance identifier is provided by these same definitions coupled with standard SNMP rules (see RFC 2578).
c)     Each message shall contain all of the objects as shown, unless otherwise indicated.
d)     A message shall not contain any other objects.
e)     The contents of each message sent by the management station may appear in any order.

NOTE—Ideally, the order of objects should match the order as shown in this document to provide for the highest probability of interoperability. However, it is recognized that many implementations may use off-the-shelf software, which may prevent the designation of an exact ordering of objects and as a result, this ordering is not a requirement of this document.
f)      After sending a message, the management station shall not transmit any other data across the communications channel until the earlier of:
1)     The management station receiving a response from the device; or,
2)     The expiration of the response time.
g)     If the response indicates an error occurred in the operation, the management station shall exit the process, unless specific error-handling rules are specified by the dialog.
h)     Dialogs containing a sequence of only GetRequest-PDUs may request objects in any order.

i)      The device shall process the GetRequest-PDUs, GetNextRequest-PDUs, GetBulkRequest-PDUs, and SetRequest-PDUs in accordance with all of the rules of NTCIP 2301, including updating the value in the database and initiating the transmission of the appropriate response (assuming that the TSS has permission to transmit) within 1 second of receiving the last byte of the request.
This section also provides a definition of state transition rules for operations that impact device state. This section is divided into four parts as follows:
a)     Tutorial—provides an overview to better understand the content of this section.

b)     Dialogs—provides the standardized data exchange sequences that can be used by management stations to ensure interoperable implementation for the various data exchange requirements identified in Section 3.4.

c)     State Tables—provides a definition of the operational states of the TSS, the semantic meaning of each state, the commands and events that can cause a state change, and the state that the device will transition to when the command or event occurs.

NOTE—To fully and clearly describe the design of the system, an object-oriented approach is adopted; however, this object-oriented design in no way imposes a requirement for an object-oriented implementation. The diagrams shown in this document are solely intended to show the details of the interface logic and static structures; the implementation may follow an object-oriented or structured approach.

The Requirements Traceability Matrix (RTM) presented in Annex A identifies the standardized dialog that can be used to achieve each of the data exchange requirements defined in Section 3.4. Some data exchange requirements reference one of the general SNMP dialogs defined in ISO 26048-1.

This section defines the standardized dialogs that are specific to this document. Each of these dialogs is defined by a number of steps. When steps reference data elements, they are included in the corresponding row of the RTM with an indication of where they are defined.

Dialogs may also be accompanied by an informative figure that provides a graphical depiction of the normative text. The figures conform to the Uniform Modeling Language (UML) and depict the management station as an outside actor sending a series of messages to the device and the device returning responses. If there is any conflict between the figure and the text, the text takes precedence.

Section 4.2 defines how the system is designed to work for a given data exchange requirement. It defines the standardized sequence of actions that a management station can follow to provide the specific service; the formal definition is sometimes depcited using a UML sequence diagram. A solid line with an arrowhead indicates initiation of a request from one entity to another (e.g., typically the management station to the device). A dashed-line with an arrowhead indicates a return value to a request (e.g., the device to the management station). Generally, the entities that initiate requests are on the left of those receiving the request. The flow of events can be followed by looking at the message lines between objects as they move across and down the page. An example sequence diagram is provided in Figure 2.
Figure 2 Sample Sequence Diagram for Output Configuration

In addition to sequence diagrams for a given dialog, there may also be a View of Participating Classes (VOPC) diagram that depicts the interrelationships among the various entities identified in the sequence diagrams. For a vast majority of cases, the dialogs for a device are simplistic enough to be described in simple list form without sequence or class diagrams.

The GetRequest-PDUs, GetNextRequest-PDUs, GetBulkRequest-PDUs, and SetRequest-PDUs  all use the varBindingList structure. RFC 3416 defines this structure as containing zero or more varBindings, where each varBinding is defined to consist of an object name (as indicated by an Object Identifier (OID)) and the associated object value (or an exception value such as unSpecified or noSuchInstance). This is relationship is depicted in Figure 3.
Figure 3 SNMP Interface—View of Participating Classes (VOPC)

children.heading: Grouping of Objects in a Request

children.text: SNMP allows a management station to send a GetRequest-PDU, GetNextRequest-PDU, GetBulkRequest-PDU, or SetRequest-PDU containing any combination of supported objects in any order, unless explicitly restricted by obect definitions and object refinements.

SNMP does not allow agents (i.e., devices) to associate any semantics with the ordering of objects within the varBindingsList. As required by RFC 3416, Clause 4.1.5, each object shall be affected "as if simultaneously with respect to all other assignments specified in the same request.”
SNMP allows a management station to send a GetRequest-PDU, GetNextRequest-PDU, or GetBulkRequest-PDU for any supported readable object within the read MIB view associated with the user.
SNMP allows the management station to send a SetRequest-PDU for any supported writable object within the write MIB view associated with the user.

SNMP allows a user with sufficient rights to configure access rights for other users. This is done by associating each user (i.e., securityName) with a user group and associating user groups with MIB views for reading, writing, and receiving notifications. Each of the MIB views are defined by identifying portions of the object identifier tree for which the user is provided or denied access.

This section provides the standardized data exchange sequences that can be used by management stations to ensure interoperable implementations for the various data exchange requirements identified in Section 3.4.
The standardized dialog for a management station to restart, reinitialize, restore, retune, re-synchronize, or run short or full diagnostics of a TSS shall be as follows:
a)     (Precondition) The management station shall be aware of the TSS value for tssRestartTimeMax.0.

b)     The management station shall send a GetRequest-PDU containing sensorSystemStatus.0. If the value of sensorSystemStatus.0 is 'initializing', 'pendingConfigurationChange', or 'validatingPendingConfiguration', then the management station shall abort the process.

c)     The management station shall send a SetRequest-PDU setting sensorSystemReset.0 to 'restart', 'reinitializeUserSettings', 'restoreFactoryDefaults', 'retune', 'resyncSamplingPeriods', 'shortDiagnostics', or 'fullDiagnostics'.
d)     The management station shall send a GetRequest-PDU containing sensorSystemStatus.0.
e)     If the management station gets no response, then it shall repeat Step d until the maximum expected TSS initialization time, as defiend by tssRestartTimeMax.0.
f)      If the sensorSystemStatus.0 state is 'initializing', then the management station shall repeat Step d.
g)     If sensorSystemStatus.0 state is 'oK', then the TSS reset is complete.

h)     If sensorSystemStatus.0 state NOT 'oK', then the reset may not have completed, did not complete normally, or an error was encountered during the process. The management station shall abort the process.
The standardized dialog for a management station to execute a pending configuration change shall be as follows:
a)     (Precondition) The management station has completed normally the Validate Pending Configuration dialog.

b)     The management station shall send a GetRequest-PDU containing sensorSystemStatus.0 state. If the state of sensorSystemStatus.0 is NOT 'pendingConfigurationChange', then the management station shall abort the process.
c)     The management station shall send a SetRequest-PDU setting sensorSystemReset.0 state to 'executePendingConfiguration'.
d)     The management station shall send a GetRequest-PDU containing sensorSytemStatus.0 state.
e)     If the management station gets no response, then it shall repeat Step d until the maximum expected TSS initialization time.
f)      If the sensorSystemStatus.0 state is 'initializing', then the management station shall repeat Step d.
g)     If the sensorSystemStatus.0 state is 'oK', then the new configuration is complete.

h)     If the sensorSystemStatus.0 state is NOT 'oK', then the Execute Pending Configuration Change may not have completed, did not complete normally, or an error was encountered during the process. The management station shall abort the process.
The standardized dialog for a management station to abort a pending configuration change shall be as follows:
a)     (Precondition) The management station has completed normally the Validate Pending Configuration dialog.

b)     The management station shall send a GetRequest-PDU containing sensorSystemStatus.0 state. If the state of sensorSystemStatus.0 is NOT 'pendingConfigurationChange', then the management station shall abort the process.
c)     The management station shall send a SetRequest-PDU setting sensorSystemReset.0 state to 'abortPendingConfiguration. The abort pending configuration is then complete.
The standardized dialog for a management station to validate a configuration file (i.e., ensure that the file is a valid configuration file) shall be as follows:

a)     (Precondition) The management station should have transferred the new configuration file prior to requesting it be validated. This is to ensure that the management station knows what configuration file is being validated by the TSS.

b)     The management station shall send a GetRequest-PDU containing sensorSystemStatus.0 state. If the state of sensorSystemStatus.0 is 'diagnosticError', then the management station shall abort the process.
c)     The management station shall send a SetRequest-PDU setting sensorSystemReset.0 state to 'validatePendingConfiguration'.
d)     The management station shall send a GetRequest-PDU containing sensorSytemStatus.0 state.
e)     If the sensorSystemStatus.0 state is 'validatingPendingConfiguration', then repeat Step d.
f)      If the sensorSystemStatus.0 state is 'pendingConfigurationChange', then the new configuration is valid and ready to execute.
g)     If the sensorSystemStatus.0 state is 'pendingConfigurationError', then the new configuration is not valid and cannot be executed.

h)     If the sensorSystemStatus.0 state is NOT 'pendingConfigurationChange' or 'pendingConfigurationError', then the Validate Pending Configuration may not have completed, did not complete normally, or an error was encountered during the process. The management station shall abort the process.
The standardized dialog for a management station to set the Build Image parameter for a machine vision TSS sensor shall be as follows:
a)     (Precondition) The sensorTechnology type shall be machineVision. The management station shall be aware of the values to be configured.
b)     The management station shall send a SetRequest-PDU containing the desired value for the following objects:
1)  imageZoneNumber.0
2)  imageType.0
3)  imageOverlayType.0
4)  imageFormat.0
5)  imageQuality.0
c)     The management station shall send a SetRequest-PDU setting the value of buildImageCmd.0 to 'buildImage'.
d)     The management station shall send a GetRequest-PDU containing buildImageStatus.0

1)     If the value of buildImageStatus.0 is 'buildingImage' or 'buildPending' then to abort buildImageCmd.0 the management station shall send a SetRequest-PDU setting the value of buildImageCmd.0 to 'cancelBuildInProgress'. The management station shall then repeat Step c.
2)     If buildImageStatus.0 is NOT 'imageReady', then an error has occurred and the value returned indicates the type of error encountered.
3)     If buildImageStatus.0 is 'imageReady', then the management station can retrieve the image via FTPS.

When in the other state, the following rules shall apply:
a)     The TSS shall process a request to set sensorSystemReset.0 to any of the following values:
1)     restart
2)     reinitializeUserSettings
3)     restoreFactoryDefaults
4)     retune
5)     resyncSamplingPeriods
6)     shortDiagnostics
7)     fullDiagnostics
8)     validatePendingConfiguration
b)     The TSS shall respond with an ‘inconsistentValue’ error for a request to set sensorSystemReset.0 to any of the following values:
1)     executePendingConfiguration
2)     abortPendingConfiguration
c)     The TSS shall respond with an ‘wrongValue’ error for a request to set sensorSystemReset.0 to ‘noResetInProgress’.
d)     The TSS shall not enter this state if the state can also transition to one of the following:
1)     pendingConfigurationChange
2)     validatingPendingConfiguration
3)     diagError
4)     activeConfigError
5)     pendingConfigError
When in the OK state, the following rule shall apply:
a)     The TSS shall process a request to set sensorSystemReset.0 to any of the following values:
1)     restart
2)     reinitializeUserSettings
3)     restoreFactoryDefaults
4)     retune
5)     resyncSamplingPeriods
6)     shortDiagnostics
7)     fullDiagnostics
8)     validatePendingConfiguration
b)     The TSS shall provide an ‘inconsistentValue’ error in response to a request to set sensorSystemReset.0 to any of the following values:
1)     executePendingConfiguration
2)     abortPendingConfiguration
c)     The TSS shall provide a ‘wrongValue’ error in response to a request to set sensorSystemReset.0 to ‘noResetInProgress’.
When in the initializing state, the following rules shall apply:
a)     The TSS shall provide an appropriate error (i.e., either inconsistentValue or wrongValue) in response to any set request continaing sensorSystemReset.0.
b)     If initialization completes successfully, sensorSystemStatus.0 shall transition to ‘oK’.
c)     If initialization is not successful, the state shall transition to diagError, activeConfigError, or other, as appropriate.
When in the pending configuration change state, the following rules shall apply:
a)     The TSS shall process a request to set sensorSystemReset.0 to any of the following values:
1)     executePendingConfiguration
2)     abortPendingConfiguration
If other commands need to be sent, an abort shall be sent first.
b)     The TSS shall provide an ‘inconsistentValue’ error in response to a request to set sensorSystemReset.0 to any of the following values:
1)     restart
2)     reinitializeUserSettings
3)     restoreFactoryDefaults
4)     retune
5)     resyncSamplingPeriods
6)     shortDiagnostics
7)     fullDiagnostics
8)     validatePendingConfiguration
c)     The TSS shall provide a ‘wrongValue’ error in response to a request to set sensorSystemReset.0 to ‘noResetInProgress’.
d)     If the TSS receives a request to set sensorSystemReset.0 to abortPendingConfiguration, the pending configuration change shall be aborted and the TSS shall return to the previous state.
e)     If the manufacturer-specified time to wait for the execution has passed, the pending configuration change shall be aborted and the TSS shall return to the previous state.

f)      If the TSS receives a request to set sensorSystemReset.0 to executePendingConfiguration, the TSS shall transition to the initializing state and begin the manufacturer-specific initialization steps.
When in the validating pending configuration state, the following rules shall apply:
a)     The TSS shall process a request to set sensorSystemReset.0 to abortPendingConfiguration (i.e., the current request must finish or be aborted prior to sending any other request)
b)     The TSS shall provide an ‘inconsistentValue’ error in response to a request to set sensorSystemReset.0 to any of the following values:
1)     restart
2)     reinitializeUserSettings
3)     restoreFactoryDefaults
4)     retune
5)     resyncSamplingPeriods
6)     shortDiagnostics
7)     fullDiagnostics
8)     executePendingConfiguration
9)     validatePendingConfiguration
c)     The TSS shall provide a ‘wrongValue’ error in response to a request to set sensorSystemReset.0 to ‘noResetInProgress’.
d)     If the TSS successfully validates the pending configuration file, the state shall change to pendingConfigurationChange.
e)     If the validation discovers a fault in the pending configuration file, the state shall change to pendingConfigError
When in the diagnostic error state, the following rules shall apply:
a)     The TSS shall process a request to set sensorSystemReset.0 to any of the following values:
1)     restart
2)     reinitializeUserSettings
3)     restoreFactoryDefaults
4)     retune
5)     resyncSamplingPeriods
6)     shortDiagnostics
7)     fullDiagnostics
b)     The TSS shall provide an ‘inconsistentValue’ error in response to a request to set sensorSystemReset.0 to any of the following values:
1)     executePendingConfiguration
2)     abortPendingConfiguration
3)     validatePendingConfiguration
c)     The TSS shall provide a ‘wrongValue’ error in response to a request to set sensorSystemReset.0 to ‘noResetInProgress’.
d)     Depending upon the manufacturer and the specific error that occurred, the TSS state may return to ‘oK’ state if the error clears
e)     The TSS shall remain in the diagnostic error state if an active configuration error also exists until a valid request to set sensorSystemReset.0 is processed.
When in the active configuration error state, the following rules shall apply:
a)     The TSS shall process a request to set sensorSystemReset.0 to any of the following values:
1)     reinitializeUserSettings
2)     restoreFactoryDefaults
3)     shortDiagnostics
4)     fullDiagnostics
5)     validatePendingConfiguration
b)     The TSS shall provide an ‘inconsistentValue’ error in response to a request to set sensorSystemReset.0 to any of the following values:
1)     restart
2)     retune
3)     resyncSamplingPeriods
4)     executePendingConfiguration
5)     abortPendingConfiguration
c)     The TSS shall provide a ‘wrongValue’ error in response to a request to set sensorSystemReset.0 to ‘noResetInProgress’.
d)     The error may be cleared at the TSS. If this happens, the state transitions to ‘oK’.
When in the pending configuration error state, the following rules shall apply:

a)     The TSS shall process a request to set sensorSystemReset.0 to abortPendingConfiguration (i.e., the current configuration process must be aborted prior to initiating another configuration request).
b)     The TSS shall provide an ‘inconsistentValue’ error in response to a request to set sensorSystemReset.0 to any of the following values:
1)     restart
2)     reinitializeUserSettings
3)     restoreFactoryDefaults
4)     retune
5)     resyncSamplingPeriods
6)     shortDiagnostics
7)     fullDiagnostics
8)     executePendingConfiguration
9)     validatePendingConfiguration
a)     The TSS shall provide a ‘wrongValue’ error in response to a request to set sensorSystemReset.0 to ‘noResetInProgress’.
c)     If the TSS receives a sensorSystemReset:abortPendingConfiguration command, the TSS transitions to either the ok or activeConfigError state, as appropriate.

This section defines those objects that are specific to transportation sensor systems (TSS). The objects are defined using the OBJECT-TYPE macro as specified in NTCIP 8004, which is based on RFC 2578 and related standards. The text provided from Section 5.1 through the end of Section 5 (except the section headings) constitutes the NTCIP1209-Tss MIB.

This section generally presents the objects in lexigraphical order of their OBJECT IDENTIFIERS, which correspond to their physical location within the global naming tree. Most of the objects defined in this document reside under the ‘tss’ node of the global naming tree. To aid in object management, the ‘tss’ node has been subdivided into logical categories, each defined by a node under the ‘tss’ node. The individual objects are then located under the appropriate node.

Conformance requirements for any object are determined by the use of the Requirements Traceability Matrix (RTM) in Annex A. To support any defined Requirement, an implementation shall support all objects to which the Requirement traces in the RTM. An implementation shall support the full standardized range of each supported object, unless otherwise noted in the object refinement table in A.5. An implementation shall indicate their level of conformance to this standard using an AGENT-CAPABILITIES statement, as defined by RFC 2580, which indicates supported OBJECT-GROUPs and object ranges.

For all bitmapped objects, if a bit is zero (0), then the referenced function is disabled, inactive, OFF, or not supported, and if a bit is one (1), then the referenced function is enabled, active, ON, or supported.

This MIB is managed by the NTCIP TSS Working Group and proprietary features should be defined through vendor-specific nodes in vendor-specific extensions to this MIB. All values not explicitly defined (e.g., enumerated values not listed, bits not defined, etc.) are reserved for future use by the TSS Working Group and shall not be used by implementations until defined by the DMS WG.

A computer readable format of this information, called a Management Information Base, is available from NEMA (ntcip@nema.org). The MIB has been verified using https://www.simpleweb.org/ietf/mibs/validate/.

Previous versions of this NTCIP 1209 defined data elements that have been replaced to resolve ambiguities; however, central systems may need to interoperate with older equipment and support such data elements. These replaced objects have a status of 'deprecated' or 'obsolete' and indicate the version in which they were deprecated or made obsolete; Annex D documents the reason that the WG decided to deprecate an obsolete the various objects within the current version.

children.heading: SENSOR CONTROL OBJECTS
children.text:
This node is an identifier used to group all objects for TSS output control data elements. A sensor zone can be mapped to any available output. Outputs report discrete activity states sensed within a zone combined with other logic. Output states should be refreshed upon change of actuation state for each associated detector or any other parameters associated with the logic.

children.heading: Speed Data Buffer
children.text:
<Description> Arithmetic mean of speeds collected over the sample period, with units of 1/10ths of km/hr, for the second most recently completed previous sample period. For a volume of zero during the sample period, the value of 65535 shall be returned to represent an invalid or missing value. A missing value is reported when the zoneStatusBuffer is anything other than OK for the entire sampling period. Values 2551 through 65534 are reserved for future use.
<Parameter Type> Status
<Superseded by> sampleSpeedData.x.3.1, where x = the sensorZoneNumber of this entry. If this object is supported, it must report the same value as the superceding object.
<Informative> This object was deprecated in NTCIP 1209 v02.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.4.3.2.1.4
children.name: speedDataBuffer

children.heading: Zone Status Buffer
children.text:
Detailed status returned as result of diagnostics, for the previous sample period, as follows:
Value Meaning
Other - Indicates an error has occurred within the TSS for which
there is no defined definition within this data element,
oK - Indicates no other status values apply,
initializing - Indicates an initialization or diagnostics procedure is
in-progress,
noActivity - Indicates no activity condition,
maxPresence - Indicates max presence condition,
configurationError - Indicates an error within the TSS configuration
setup,
erraticCounts - Indicates erratic counts,
disabled - Indicates that the zone is disabled,
overrideActive - Indicates an override is active,
sensorFailure - Indicates a sensing element failure.

If a condition occurs during the sample period, then that state remains for the duration of that sample period. If multiple conditions occur during a sample period, the last reported condition, other than OK, is retained.
<Parameter Type> Status
<Superseded by> sampleZoneStatus.x.3.1, where x = the sensorZoneNumber of this entry. If this object is supported, it must report the same value as the superceding object.
<Informative> This object was deprecated in NTCIP 1209 v02.

children.heading: INDUCTIVE LOOP DETECTOR OBJECTS
children.text:
This node contains the configuration objects specific to inductive loop detectors. These objects set up physical parameters on the detector that are controlled on a per output basis. These objects are only valid for the zones that map directly to an output on the detector. Zone 1 maps to output 1 and Zone 2 maps to output 2 on a two-channel sensor unit and Zone 3 maps to output 3, and Zone 4 maps to output 4 on a four-channel sensor unit. For inductive loop detectors, the term 'channel' is often used to refer to an 'output'.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.4.4

children.text: The Requirements Traceability Matrix (RTM) links the Functional Requirements as presented in Section 3 with the corresponding Dialogs (Section 4.2) on the same (gray) line. Each Functional Requirement/Dialog relates/uses one or more groups of Objects. The Objects (also known as Data Elements) are listed to the side; the formal definition of each object is contained within Section 5. Using this table, each Functional Requirement can thus be traced in a standardized way.
Note: The INDEX objects into any of the tables are not explicitly exchanged but are used as index values for other objects that are exchanged.

The audience for this table is implementers (vendors and central system developers) and conformance testers. Additionally, other interested parties might use this table to determine how particular functions are to be implemented using the standardized dialogs, interfaces, and object definitions.

To conform to a Functional Requirement, a DMS shall implement all Objects and Dialogs traced from that Functional Requirement; a Management Station shall implement all Dialogs traced from the Functional Requirement. to be consistent with a Functional Requirement, a Management Station shall be able to fulfill the Functional Requirement using only Objects and Dialogs that a conforming DMS is required to support.

Error! Reference source not found. defines Supplemental Requirements, which are refining other functional requirements. These functional requirements in turn are generally traced to design elements (e.g., rather than being directly traced to design elements). The Supplemental RTM in Section A.4 below identifies and traces the implied relationships between supplemental requirements and direct requirements.

Error! Reference source not found. defines the 'Mark-Up Language for Transportation Information' (MULTI), which defines tags that can be used within the text of a DMS message to define its display on the face of the DMS display. The Multi Field Traceability Matrix in Section A.5 below identifies and traces the implied relationships between MULTI tags and direct requirements.

The functional requirements are defined within Section 3 and the RTM is based upon the requirements within that Section. The section number and the functional requirement name are indicated within these columns.
The standardized dialogs are defined within Section 4 and the RTM references the traces from requirements to this dialog. The section number of the dialog is indicated within this column.

The objects are defined within Section 5 of NTCIP 1203 v3 and Section 2 of NTCIP 1201. The RTM references the data objects that are referenced by the dialog.  The section number and object name are indicated within these columns.

The "Additional Specifications" column may (and should) be used to provide additional notes and requirements about the dialog or may be used by an implementer to provide any additional details about the implementation.

To find the standardized design content for a functional requirement, search for the requirement identification number and functional requirement under the functional requirements columns. Next to the functional requirements column will be a dialog identification number, identifying either a generic dialog (found in Section G.3) or a specified dialog (found in Section 4.2) to be used to fulfill that requirement. To the right of the dialog identification number are the identification number and name of the data objects that are referenced or used by the dialog to fulfill the functional requirement. Object definitions specific to NTCIP 1203 v3 can be found in Section 5. If an object is defined in a different standard, that standard shall be listed first, followed by the section number where the object definition can be found. The "Additional Specifications" column will provide additional notes or details about the design content.
Per RFC 2580, MIB modules can include MODULE-COMPLIANCE macros to define:
·       When each object-group must be supported.
·       When object-types can be sub-ranged within an AGENT-CAPABILITIES statement,
·       To what extent access to objects can be restricted within implementations,
·       Which object types were introduced and deprecated within each version of the standard,
·       When refinements were made to the valid syntax of objects (e.g., new or deprecated enumerations),
IETF MIB modules typically contain one MODULE-COMPLIANCE statement for each revision of the module.

NTCIP standards define when each object-type must be supported using the PRL and RTM traceability tables. These tables allow the reader to better understand the user needs behind each object-type. Some of the other details mentioned above are often discussed within object descriptions, requirements, or other locations within the standard. However, some issues, such as when objects were added or ranges changed are seldom discussed in other portions of the document.

Rather than using MODULE-COMPLIANCE macros within each MIB module, the NTCIP standards include a version conformance table and an object refinement table to provide identical information in a more concise manner that does not complicate the MIB modules. These tables are provided to ensure that these implementation issues are documented within the standard and to provide a single summary area for this information. It is recognized that these tables duplicate and extend requirements contained within object-type descriptions, the PRL, and the RTM. In case of any conflict between these sources the object-type descriptions, PRL, and RTM take precedence over the version conformance table and object refinement table.
Table 1 indicates which object groups and capabilities are required for each version of NTCIP 1203 for the objects contained within this MIB, starting with NTCIP 1203 v04.
Table 1: Version Conformance for NTCIP1203-Dms MIB
To conform to this MIB, implementations shall:
•       support the defined MAX-ACCESS of each supported object, unless the object refinement table indicates a different minimum access;
•       support at least the access defined when the object refinement table indicates a refined access for the object type;
•       support the full range of values defined by the SYNTAX for each supported object, unless the object refinement table indicates a different SYNTAX;
•       support at least the range of values defined when the object refinement table indicates a refined syntax for the object type.
NOTE — The refined access or syntax includes any text in the DESCRIPTION field.

Figure 7 provides a graphical representation of the Traffic Sensor System Object Tree.
Figure 7 Object Tree for this document
Annex C is a placeholder for test procedures content in a future major version.

Annex D identifies changes that have been made to this document since the last major version (i.e., NTCIP 1209 v02) that required the deprecation of objects and identifies whty these changes have been made. NTCIP makes reasonable efforts to ensure that NTCIP standards accommodate multi-version interoperability (MVI-backward compatibility) to the extent possible; however, in the case of this version, the upgrade to a more secure environment and the updated protocol prohibit direct backwards compatibility with prior versions. This fact also led to the decision to address other issues that were less critical (e.g., shifting to a time format that has a longer horizon before a roll-over event). Nonetheless, efforts have been made to allow for the creation of proxy agents that can translate between the new design and prior designs with relatively minor complications.

When revisions are required, problematic objects are deprecated and, in most cases, are replaced with new objects. Replaced objects may be superseded (i.e., if an implementation supports both the original and replacement objects, the values of the two objects are interrelated and change together) or supplanted (i.e., while there is a replacement object with similar functionality, the values represent distinct instances that do not affect each other).

To maintain MVI for legacy implementations (through a proxy agent), objects with a STATUS value of “deprecated” may require support and for this reason, this document includes these objects and has updated them to the new MIB format so that they can be exchanged across an SNMPv3 link. When communicating with implementations conforming to versions of NTCIP 1209 prior to v03, a proxy agent is responsible for converting between the SNMPv3 data as presented in this document (i.e., per RFC 2578) and SNMPv1 data as presented in prior versions of NTCIP 1209 (i.e., per RFC 1212). Although the presentation of these objects have been updated, their OBJECT IDENTIFIERs remain the same.

The primary intent in producing the NTCIP 1209 v03 update was to improve the security of TSS per the recommendations of NTCIP 9014. The decision to migrate to SNMPv3 requires the conversion of all NTCIP MIBs to SMIv2 format, as specified in RFC 2578. Notable edits in this category are noted in the following subsections.
SMIv2 imposes stricter requirements on the semantics of counter objects. As a result, the way that NTCIP devices store time is different than in prior versions. This resulted in:
·       The syntax of endTime, endTimeBuffer, and sampleEndTime were changed from Counter to Unsigned32 to conform to SMIv2 rules.
·       sampleEndTime was deprecated and superseded with sampleEndDateStamp, sampleEndTimeStamp, and sampleEndTimeTicks.
General edits have been made to the MIB header in this document to:
·       Update the module name to reflect current conventions
·       Update the imports statement, especially to reflect imports from theSNMPv3 and ISO 26048-1 MIBs
·       Incorporate the description of the MIB in the MODULE-IDENTITY macro
·       Formally define textual conventions for structures defined locally within the module
·       Refine the nodes used to group objects to become formal OBJECT-IDENTITY macros
Units defined in the DESCRIPTION clause were moved to the SMIv2 UNITS clause.
The ACCESS clause (used in SMIv1 MIBS) was replaces with the MAX-ACCESS (used in SMIv2).
Per the definition of the STATUS clause in SMIv2, the values "mandatory" and "optional" were replaced with "current". Mandatory and optional conformance is indicated in the PRL.
The syntax of ranged integers was changed from INTEGER to Integer32 to align with SMIv2 rules.
The following subclauses have been added within each DESCRIPTION field as appropriate within the MIB. These fields are distinguished with chevrons (i.e., "<"  and ">").

·       Superseded by: included in deprecated objects to indicate a replacement object when the replacement object's value is linked to the original object's value (e.g., sampleEndTime and sampleEndTimeStamp are linked in the sense that both have the same semantic meaning - just the formats change)
·       Informative: Indicates non-normative, helpful text about the object type
·       Parameter Type: Indicates whether the object type is status, control, a parameter, or interrelated parameter.
NOTE—The "supplanted by" subclause, which indicates a replacement object's value is not linked to the original object's value,  is not used in this document.

To provide adequate security, NTCIP no longer allows the use of SNMPv1 or STMP. Likewise, the security tables defined in NTCIP 1103 have been replaced by the structures processes defined for SNMPv3, as formally defined in ISO 15784-2. A summary of these requirements can be viewed at https://standards.iso.org/iso/15784/-2/ed-2/en/.

children.heading: Using ISO 26048-1 rather than NTCIP 1201 and NTCIP 1103

children.text: The NTCIP standards are now being developed in coordination with similar, international efforts of ISO/TC 204. Rather than duplicating a similar set of secure object-type definitions, object-types and textual conventions that are applicable to a wide array of devices are managed under ISO 26048-1 and this document normatively references portions of this standard. The MIBs included in ISO 26048-1 are available at https://standards.iso.org/iso/ts/26048/-1/ed-1/en/.

While many of the objects defined in ISO 26048-1 are similar to objects previously defined in NTCIP 1201, virtually all of these objects had at least one known technical issue that justified an update.
The MIB has been updated to make use of ITSBitmap and ITSUByteString rather than the BITMAP formats of NTCIP 1209 v02.

Several of the BITMAP objects were deprecated due to interoperability challenges resulting from encoding rules that were somewhat counter-intuitive as follows:

The architectural needs previously defined in this document are now addressed by ISO 26048-1 user needs.
The NTCIP 1201 objects referenced for version information (e.g., the moduleTable) have been replaced by ISO 26048-1 user needs that trace to the entity MIB (RFC 6933).
The object that indicated wheather the device supported a real-time clock has been deprecated. This can be determined by querying fdClockLocalTime.

The sampleEndTime object was deprecated because local time is now recorded in fdClockLocalDate and fdClockLocalTime rather than controllerLocalTime. The object has been  superseded by sampleEndDateStamp, sampleEndTimeStamp, and sampleEndTimeTicks.

The syntax for text-based objects (e.g., sensorZoneLable) was updated from OCTET STRING to SnmpAdminString to indicate that they can potentially include UTF-8 characters. UTF-8 extends NVT-ASCII to support virtually all known languages.
The object refinement table only requires implementations to support NVT-ASCII.

The definition of maxNumberOfCharacters was updated to indicate that it identifies the number of octets within the labels rather than characters (i.e., the prior definition improperly implied that a two-octet character would be counted as one character rather than two octets).

The object outputModeStatus had a technical problem in that bit 6 was defined to indicate that either override 'on' or override 'off'; there was no way to indicate that an override was not active. The outputModeStatus was superseded with outputModeStatusV3.

Because the conversion to SNMPv3 prevents any dialog from being backwards compatible with prior versions, the NTCIP community determined that it was appropriate to correct other known issues that had been discovered over the decades of successful NTCIP deployments.
The <Definition> clause of many objects were revised to provide clarification.

Object-types with bitmap syntax were revised to use ITSBitmap and the descriptions were revised to align with the bit numbering scheme used by ITSBitmap. The physical ordering of the bits do not change.
The syntax of sensorZoneAndOperator and sensorZoneOrOperator were updated to be ITSUByteString rather than BITMAP64 to more accurately reflect the contents of a series of 1-octet integers.

children.heading: Deletion of Backward Compatible User Need

children.text: The conversion to SNMPv3 prevents any dialog from being backwards compatible with prior versions of NTCIP. In order to prevent an implication that backwards compatibility is supported by this document, all backards compatibility user needs and requirements have been removed from this document.

A user need was added to the security section and this is traced to a security requirement that prohibits implementations from supporting prior versions of SNMP unless they can be disabled. It also defines two classes of devices: "conformant" devices do not support less secure protocols while "consistent" devices support less secure protocols that can be disabled.

children.heading: Providing Guidance to Deployments for Security

children.text: Within the operational policies section, (2.7), text was added to provide security guidance to deployers of the equipment.
Many of the requireemnts now trace to generic dialogs defined in ISO 26048-1 rather than specifying custom dialogs within Section 4.
The upgrade to SNMPv3 refined some of the ways that requirements for conformance are presented as noted in the following subsections.

Previous versions of NTCIP allowed implementations to subrange objects. For example, An object with a standardized range of 0..255 could be subranged (e.g., to 1..10). In SNMPv3, implementations are required to support the full standardized range of each object unless an exception is explcitly defined. Within new NTCIP documents, these exceptions are documented in the object refinement table (A.5).
Rather than defining architectural user needs and other generic needs and requirements within this document, the user is referred to ISO 26048-1.
The reference architecture defined in 2.3 was updated to use ARC-IT conventions.

children.heading: Relationship to the National ITS Architecture

children.text: The section describing the relationship to the National ITS Architecture (ARC-IT) was updated.
A number of other changes were made to the text to clarify issues and to be more consistent with the updated NTCIP style guide and for consistency in boilerplate with other documents.
